title: Opening Remarks: Hugh Forrest
speaker: Hugh Forrest
description: Chief Programming Officer Hugh Forrest covers the various changes, additions and improvements for the 2017 event, plus shares a few tips on how to leverage all the opportunities at March Magic in Austin. This talk will also focus on the role an engaged, forward-thinking community in making SXSW such a special gathering. Forrest will spend a few minutes answering event-related questions from the audience at the end of this session.

title: It's Not Ready Yet: The Perfectionist's Struggle
speaker: Christine Herrin
description: The creative process has always been different for everyone, but it’s always a process: of knowing, not knowing, questioning, deciding, and making. Graphic designer, handletterer, and Adobe Creative Resident Christine Herrin will share her own process and her struggles with perfectionism in finishing projects that don't feel "done", and hopefully at the end will get you thinking about you live, work, get inspired, and create.

title: Actionable Gamification for the Win
speaker: Yu-kai Chou
description: Talks on gamification often expand on theory and the potential to solve a wide range of problems. However, few provide a methodology for determining the nature of the challenge and design for an effective solution. A Gamification pioneer and International keynote speaker, Yu-Kai Chou presents a systematic approach to implement effective gameful design for any process. Using an actionable gamification approach, the elements of human motivation become the salient factors in the design process. Instead of focusing on game elements like points, badges, and leaderboards, Yu-kai will break down motivation into the eight Core Drives that inspire people to engage and learn through game techniques.

title: How Tech is Shaping the Future of Entertainment
speaker: Natalie Jarvey
description: Pete Cashmore, Founder and CEO of Mashable, will sit down with leaders in the entertainment and technology space to discuss how television and film are working hand in hand with Silicon Valley to not only reach consumers in the new ways they're watching videos, but adjusting their creative process based on new advances in audience data.

title: Internet Kill Switch? Who’s Got the Keys?
speaker: Christian Dawson
description: Are you online right now?  Maybe you’re on your phone, tablet, or laptop. Maybe you’re even reading messages on your watch! The seamless access to everything on the Internet is akin to the air we breathe. We don’t give it a second thought. Type in a URL and BOOM! You order a product from Nepal. From connecting doctors with patients for better health care to kick-starting the next charitable organization, the Internet can be a tool for tremendous global good. But it can also be a tool for criminal activity. Who keeps a watchful eye over the Internet globally? Is there such a thing as an INTERNET KILL SWITCH?  Is the backbone of the Internet safe against attack?

title: SXSW Release It Round 1
speaker: Trey Bowles
description: SXSW Release It is a special pitch competition in Startup Village on the opening day of the SXSW Conference. Ten cutting-edge companies launching a new product or service during this SXSW season will present to a panel of judges comprised of technology industry experts, venture capitalists, and high-profile media. The winner will then be chosen based on which product or service is most likely to succeed in the marketplace.

title: 3D Printing Hype Cycle: An Intro to 3D Printing
speaker: Dan Grigoras
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Let's Get Agile: Hack Your Project
speaker: Andrea Fryrear
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Getting to Yes: Communication and Entrepreneurship
speaker: Mark Davis
description: Communication is a key component to successful negotiations. Entrepreneurs who are working with start-ups need to have a specialized communication skill set in order to get to “yes” from launch to IPO. Knowing your audience is important, but knowing how to communicate with them takes strategy. This session is a conversation among three people that have pioneered teaching science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) students to communicate complex concepts to those who are not well versed in STEM concepts. Additionally, one of the panelists has launched several biotech companies.

title: Imgur's Fight to Keep the Social Internet Authentic
speaker: Alan Schaaf
description: Imgur's brother-sister leadership team are at an inflection point. In just a few years, Imgur skyrocketed to millions of users and became one of the most-trafficked sites in the world. Now, Imgur is on a mission to democratize entertainment by giving people the power to surface the world’s most entertaining content. In this session with Inc., hear how Imgur is building a new type of entertainment destination by breaking people outside of their expected feeds and friends' lists, and into a world of authentic, serendipitous content and community.

title: SA After Techstars, Move Over Hallmark
speaker: David Henry
description: Ever wondered about joining an incubator or accelerator program? Come and join COO, David Henry, of Card Isle on life in San Antonio after Techstars. Henry will give first hand knowledge of what it takes to prepare yourself and your company for a tech accelerator as well as what San Antonio has had to offer the company and his team post-program, pitch and funding round.

title: Privacy in Emerging Health Technologies
speaker: Kate Black
description: Technology innovation and adoption has been rapidly increasing and with it comes a number of questions around data privacy, including health data. With multiple generations engaging mobile devices, social tools, etc, there are now different levels of comfort around privacy. In order to address the concerns of different consumers, we must first understand the fears and issues, legitimate or otherwise. It is only with this information that we will be able to continue innovating. 23andMe’s Privacy Officer will present what the company has learned from its customers and discuss how this info can broadly inform the next generation of digital health products.

title: The Rise of Academic Incubators
speaker: Michael K Young
description: In response to the growth of entrepreneurial endeavors, universities are responding with pathways, such as curriculum enhancements, mentorship programs, and physical incubator space, to facilitate connections to students, potential investors and industry leaders. Incorporating these components keeps universities competitive and attractive and therefore better able to retain talented students and faculty. This panel discussion will bring together national policy-makers, industry leaders, commercial funding partners and higher education administrators from diverse higher education models.

title: Influencing Impact: Through Story and Innovation
speaker: Noor Tagouri
description: Talk description: Everyone says they want to change the world, but many don't know how to start. The change starts with discovering one's own unique passion & talents, and then aligning those with their own personal values.  From there, the realm of social impact is endless, but there will always be challenges along the way. Journalist Noor Tagouri will share personal stories of struggles & success, and how to think about scaling your impact in the world.

title: A Quick and (Rather) Dirty Machine Learning Intro
speaker: Inmar Givoni
description: So you’ve heard about Machine Learning, Deep Learning, AI. Maybe played around with it a bit. If you’d like to find out more about how it actually works under the hood, this will be a good place to start. Let’s take a bit of a deep dive into the guts of several algorithms, while keeping it entertaining.

title: Interactive Opening Speaker: Cory Booker
speaker: Cory Booker
description: New Jersey Senator and former Newark Mayor Cory Booker has established himself as an innovative and bipartisan problem-solver committed to developing collaborative solutions that address some of our most complex challenges. Booker will be the opening speaker at SXSW 2017.

title: Learn the Basics of Hand Lettering 1
speaker: Adam Vicarel
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Augmented Reality and Urban Revitalization
speaker: Mona Lalwani
description: John Hanke, CEO and founder of Niantic Labs and Sam Gill of the Knight Foundation will discuss the potential for Augmented Reality and other mobile technologies to engage communities in dialogue and activity around public spaces. Each have a unique approach towards connecting community members, such as Niantic’s mobile games Ingress and Pokemon GO and Knight Foundation projects such as the “Reimagining the Civic Commons” initiatives in cities like Detroit, Akron and Philadelphia and the wildly successful Open Streets events, which celebrate public spaces. John and Sam will look at ways that technology can pull people out of their homes and encourage them to “rediscover” public spaces, generating foot traffic, economic activity and cultural awareness in redeveloping neighborhoods.

title: A Global Muslim Startup Ecosystem Emerges
speaker: Abrar Hussain
description: One of the most unique global markets that is emerging today is the global Muslim market. Shaped in large part by a global culture shaped by social media that breaks down traditional barriers between diverse Muslim communities, this upwardly mobile, identity-focused group includes over 500 million people between the ages of 18-25 who are seeking to have their identities validated in an uncertain world and have disposable income to pay for it.  As this market increasingly takes on uniform behaviors and habits, how can we address these market needs in ways that respect this new identity yet avoid the pitfalls of commercialization, geopolitical strife, and increased anti-Muslim sentiment?

title: Austin's Best VR/AR Startups
speaker: Mikey Trafton
description: In 60 minutes you'll learn about five of Austin's Best Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) Startups in a fun and fast-paced pitch session. Each entrepreneur will get five minutes to demo their solution and then they will get grilled by a panel of Hardware CEO's. Already recognized as one of the top cities for entrepreneurs in the US, Austin has a strong gaming history and lots of raw talent producing VR/AR content and tools. Come see what everyone's so excited about! These startups are all part of the Capital Factory Accelerator. Capital Factory is Austin's center of gravity for entrepreneurs with coworking, events, classes, mentors and a unique matching investment fund.

title: Hustle: How Money, Meaning and Momentum Find Us
speaker: Jonas Koffler
description: Too often we feel like underdogs fighting a system that stacks the odds against us. We work hard, follow the rules, and dream of a better life. But these days, working harder doesn’t always lead to fulfillment. In fact, according to Gallup research, nearly 90 percent of people feel disconnected from their jobs. So how do you break free from the drudgery and achieve more success on your own terms?

title: What's Brand Got To Do With It?
speaker: Ann Walsh
description: You work for the company that produces the best running app ever yet, as an employee, you can’t access your benefits unless you’re at work computer. The world’s changed and we expect it to interact with us as freely as we do it – so why do we, as employees, get stiffed on the regular?

title: Shaping Reality for AR Storytelling
speaker: Martin Nahuel Rabaglia
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Social Entrepreneurship for Founders: Five Things
speaker: Neetal Parekh
description: The world is changing, and so is the way do business. 2015 marked the first year millennials made up the majority of workforce. Not to be outdone, it also marked the year when baby boomers were twice as likely to start a business than millennials. The notable trend for both of these groups---a marked focus on using skills and companies to create or further social impact.

title: Baking Inclusivity and Accessibility Into Software
speaker: Holly Gibson
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Digital Copycats: Escaping Plato's Cave
speaker: Karwai Ng
description: Companies are adopting a cookie-cutter approach to design, resulting in experiences that feel oddly similar. Uber. Lyft. Warby Parker. Casper. It’s cut and paste.

title: How Wounded Warriors Are Transforming Biotech
speaker: Cali Solorio
description: Can biomechanical technology expand human potential? Advances in prosthetic technology may be blurring the lines between man and machine, but true technological breakthroughs wouldn’t be possible without individuals who are constantly pushing the limits. Meet three wounded warriors whose will to move beyond their physical limitations is transforming prosthetic technology. Hear inspirational stories of how they reclaimed their lives after devastating injuries and are now using the power of advanced prosthetic technology to live lives filled with accomplishments beyond their expectations — from competing in the Paralympics and Invictus Games to returning to active pilot duty.

title: Innovation Techniques from Kindergarten
speaker: Claudia Perez
description: Share. Learn. Make Friends. Three things we learned in kindergarten are still very much applicable in health care innovation today. In fact these three principles form the very foundation of a thriving innovation community, the Innovation Learning Network (ILN), which comes together to creatively tackle health care challenges big and small.  Come prepared to participate in this interactive session and learn how to apply human centered design, analogous observations of different industries, new innovative and creative approaches, such as storytelling, to healthcare and experience firsthand how with these pillars of sharing, learning, and connecting, we can solve anything.

title: The Evolution of the Design Process with Adobe XD
speaker: Hoyle Wang
description:
Screen design has evolved. The way designers work, the tools they use and the screens for which they design all have changed rapidly. Designers are struggling to express interactivity and flow with static screens and mockups. The increasing competition for users attention adds to these challenges. Hoyle Wang, a product manager for Adobe XD, shares what he has learned from designers about these hurdles and how the team building Adobe XD are addressing these needs so that designers can solve modern challenges.
Hoyle will present an overview on designing, prototyping, and sharing in Adobe XD, as well as top features and time saving tip and tricks.

title: Wireless Network Innovation: Smart City Foundation
speaker: Howard Wright
description: Cities across the US are integrating connected technologies and becoming “smart cities” in efforts to improve the urban experience. But what does this mean? What are the most recent smart city developments? What are the opportunities and challenges? Attend and learn directly from some of the nation’s leading Smart City voices. US Ignite will provide a wide lens perspective of US cities large and small, outlining available resources. Atlanta Mayor Reed will bring the experience of a city leader tasked with visioning and achieving smart city status. Executives Kathleen Grillo (Verizon) and Howard Wright (Intel) will give insight to what smart city technology can do and actionable next steps.

title: Networking Sucks. Build Communities People Love
speaker: Ben Thoma
description: Formal networking is dumb. It is impersonal, one-sided, and even a little awkward. Good networking comes from building awesome communities where it is a natural byproduct. A community should be a safe space where peers can communicate ideas, create lasting friendships, and empower others to break out of their comfort zone. These traits naturally occur in the presence of trust and inclusion, but are rare in impersonal communities. From local groups to national organizations to podcast communities, our panel of successful leaders will discuss how to create a community that people absolutely love.

title: Meditation & Mindfulness in Today's Changing World 1
speaker: Tish Cotto
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Solidarity with Strangers, Health for All
speaker: Patricia Illingworth
description: Should citizens provide immigrants with health care?  Despite the right to health, few countries ensure that all immigrants receive the same healthcare as citizens. Although immigrants are typically younger and healthier than citizens and often bear the burden of caretaking for citizens and their families, many citizens blame immigrants for their health problems.  In turn, nations create exclusionary policies that discriminate against newcomers.  Sometimes rich nations have shaped the conditions that drive the global poor to leave their native countries.  But one person’s health can affect the health of others and good health can benefit many.  Given the public dimensions of health, failure to help newcomers in need of care is not only counterproductive because it puts the health of all at risk, but it also violates basic principles of fairness, reciprocity and justice.  Health for all requires solidarity with others.

title: Funding Our Future: Investing in Diverse Startups
speaker: Erik Moore
description: With the growing trend of more tech startups being founded by Women, Latino, Black and Asian founders, greater investment in these ventures is needed to ensure the innovation and economic growth across all communities that these founders represent as the global population becomes more diverse. This panel consists of some of the very few Black investors within the venture capital industry. including Base Ventures and Connectivity Capital Partners. Hear their views on how to increase the capital needed to support the growth and diversity of startups. Additionally, we will discuss how to engage more diverse chambers of commerce as resources for connecting startup founders with capital.

title: SEO's at SXSW Meet Up
speaker: Danny Ashton
description: Companies in the United States will spend $65 billion on SEO this year and by 2020, this is set to rise to $79.27 billion. Even though technical SEO is still important, content creation & promotion has become a big part of SEO in 2016. Achieving measurable results with content requires creativity, and that's one of the main reasons why we are all here at SXSW: to get inspired. Agency folk, in-house specialists, freelancers, entrepreneurs lets come together to discuss what works for SEO in 2017 and share how SXSW has inspired us.

title: Learning the Language of Leadership
speaker: Brian Sullivan
description: Leaders know how to persuade and inspire with the power of their words. Their personal authority is not from their positional power. Leaders use language that speaks to us. Like any other language, you must learn, practice, and sharpen the language of leadership.

title: Women in the Creative Industry Meet Up
speaker: Chante Linwood
description: Calling all women entrepreneurs, freelancers, artists, business-owners and side hustlers. Join the founders of Austin's own #bossbabesATX and Chicago's Cliche Collective for an hour of mingling and conversation covering women in the workplace, professional resources for entrepreneurs and goal-mapping for 2017. Following mixer activities, we'll close with curated discussion, drawing from topics posed by those in attendance.

title: Portugal: Your Startup's Gateway to Europe
speaker: Marco Bravo
description: In the past couple of years, Portugal has emerged as a vibrant and competitive gateway to Europe, for startups from all around the world. Abundant English-speaking talent, top wi-fi and tech infra-structures, direct daily flights to all the major European cities, affordable cost of living, the ease of setting up business and radiant sunshine throughout most of the year are some of the reasons why more and more entrepreneurs and investors are moving to cities such as Aveiro, Braga Lisbon or Oporto. In 2016, aggressive public policies added-up to all this, such as tax benefits to early stage investors, Startup Visas for foreign founders, Startup Vouchers to fund new companies and a network of over 120 incubators. Come find out why Portugal is NOT the new London.

title: The Power of Hello: Maximizing SXSW Meet Up
speaker: Thom Singer
description: Attending an event like SXSW can be full of opportunity. The networking opportunities are amazing, but you have to be intentional in how you go about making meaningful connections.

title: The Business Case for LGBT Equality
speaker: Karrie League
description: In a majority of states, there are no clear state laws banning discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity.  Over the past two years, there have been bills and ballot initiatives proposed and passed that eliminate non-discrimination protections or that explicitly authorize discrimination by individuals, businesses, and state and local agencies. These policies have already had a devastating impact on the ability to attract the best talent and investment in states like North Carolina and Indiana.  How can the tech industry make a strong business case for equality to defeat these measures?

title: Corporate Social Responsibility Meet Up
speaker: Megan Trotter
description: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives can span the globe and cover an array of issues. At Zendesk, our CSR programming focuses on issues that are right in our backyards around the world. Through our neighborhood focused approach we have been able to better engage our employees and take part in local community action. Yet, using this framework around the world can have it's challenges. As we think locally and act globally, our issues and concerns change. From areas with strong welfare nets to those with increasing poverty, developing community programming with a localized focus has had it's bumps. Learn how Zendesk and the Zendesk Neighbor Foundation have navigated this.

title: Retaining Volunteer Talent in Your Community
speaker: Kate Baucherel
description: Volunteers aren't employees, but they add enormous value to a nonprofit organisation: they are not a free resource, but are often treated like one. From co-ordination to reporting, volunteers can find themselves in limbo, which can be equally damaging to the organisation as to the individual. How can a professional online community management approach deliver long term sustainability? Volunteers value the social relationships and knowledge sharing that comes with their roles. Sustainable volunteering depends on building and developing collaborative relationships: good communication all round! Developing a community of volunteers builds trust, and nurtures personal and organisational goals.

title: Programming with Purpose
speaker: Ken Tabor
description: Design shapes our feelings. It generates responses from a fundamentally human place inside each of us. It happens as we touch real-world objects and internalize the virtual reality of software.

title: You’re an “Innovator.” Then What?
speaker: Deborah Hankin
description: Lately, the conversation about finding creative people has been overwhelmingly singular: As a candidate, how do you position yourself as an innovator? Or, as a company, how do you attract innovative, creative talent?

title: Product Mavericks: Top Tips From Women Who Build
speaker: Merci Grace
description: From leading video on Facebook to the CTO for the first woman presidential candidate, there’s no question that there are a group of female leaders taking over in the space of product development and they’ve without a doubt made it to top. Come hear from the women who are defying the numbers, building the products we’re all using each and every day, and are both figuratively and physically shaping our future.

title: Live Q&A at SXSW: #AskGaryVee with Gary Vaynerchuk
speaker: Gary Vaynerchuk
description: You may have seen Gary Vaynerchuk’s keynotes or watched his day-in-the-life videos showing this business leader and true hustler in action. Now, get ready to go even more in-depth with @GaryVee in this SXSW edition of #AskGaryVee. In this talk, you’ll get to ask SXSW legend and master of business-building, marketing, social media, entrepreneurship and life-hacking anything and everything you’ve ever wanted to know. Expect no-holds-barred answers.

title: Women's Representation: Five Steps to Win Gender Parity
speaker: Abby Livingston
description: Panelists will discuss current numbers of women serving in office in the United States and globally, efforts to prepare individual women to run for office, and innovative strategies to reform recruitment rules and voting systems to win parity.

title: Bugs in the System: Mapping the Vulns Market
speaker: Ari Schwartz
description: Apple's legal fight with the FBI over iPhone encryption--and the FBI's highly-publicized purchase of a hacking tool to defeat that encryption--put a new spotlight on the shadowy market for software vulnerabilities. Who discovers, buys, and sells these "vulns" and the hacking tools that rely on them? When should the government disclose the vulns it buys or discovers, and how can software companies convince bug-hunters to disclose vulns so they can be fixed, rather than selling them to criminals or governments? Experts with expertise ranging from Silicon Valley to the White House to the hacker community will debate and discuss the latest developments around these controversial questions.

title: Govt and Tech Collaboration in the US and Canada
speaker: Machell Town
organization: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
description: Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control, and Public Health Agency of Canada present their work with tech to tackle the burden of disease. Historically to understand chronic disease and health behaviors (nutrition, alcohol consumption, physical activity, obesity, and sleep) we have relied in part on self-reported information. The advancement and integration of technology has made it possible to understand behaviors and their relation to disease on an unimaginable scale, in real-time. Leveraging data from wearables, search and geolocation, public/private partnerships in the US and Canada are addressing these public health challenges in innovative ways.

title: Political Strategy for Legalizing Marijuana
speaker: Montel Williams
description: The Marijuana Policy Project’s Rob Kampia will moderate a discussion around what led to the sudden shift in marijuana laws across the country. Panelists will go on to predict which states will be next to pass both medical and adult-use marijuana legislation and to debate what needs to happen in order for Congress to change federal marijuana policy? Which states are next in line to pass marijuana legislation, and what factors determine when states are ready to push for reform?

title: Humans, Machines & the Future of Industrial Design
speaker: Jason Robinson
description: In today’s digitally-mediated world, designers translate ideas back and forth between the richly poetic language of the physical world and the logical parameters in Computer-Aided Design tools.  As these tools develop to understand more of our intuitive human knowledge, they will have the ability to become intelligent collaborators in our creative process.  How will the objects and activities of design change in this future?  Through exploring how objects ‘work’, this talk considers how an acute understanding of this design language can make us better designers and help to develop more intuitive computational design tools that provoke and democratize a ‘new’ industrial design process.

title: The Risks of the Quantified Mind
speaker: Sophia Yeres
description: With Google, Apple and Amazon racing to embed voice services across our devices, conversational user interfaces will soon become ubiquitous. But the shift from screens to voice unlocks a new set of concerns for personalization, distinct from Netflix's recommendations or Google's filter bubbles. As advances in natural language understanding and affective computing take hold, assistants will rely on a vast, textured data set of choices, memories and desires in the past to condition our lives in the future. How can we navigate this tradeoff between personalization and emotional growth, and design successful personal assistants that still leave space for the user to grow, change and forget?

title: Beyond Fintech: Blockchain for Every Industry
speaker: Ann Greenberg
description: If you haven’t been tracking blockchain because you thought it was just for cryptocurrencies and fintech startups, it’s time to start. Innovators in banking (U.S. Bank), entertainment (Sceneplay) and technology (Cisco and Cognizant) will get your brain buzzing about blockchain’s broader potential by sharing how they’re using it to speed lending, turn scripts into 21st century collaboration tools, document refugees and more. You’ll understand how distributed ledger tech can store any kind of content in a way that evolves it into a verified, immutable source of truth—and leave able to apply blockchain’s principles and possibilities to your own work. Part of the IEEE Tech for Humanity Series.

title: Technology and Pet Lovers Meet Up
speaker: Kirsten Erickson
description: Calling all engineers, technical people, pet lovers and anyone interested in hearing what it takes to be a ‘whole professional’ in the technology industry. Join the CTO of DogVacay, the leading online and mobile pet-sitting community, for an hour of mingling and conversation where you will be challenged to explore the way you think so that you can become a ‘whole professional.’ How you do anything is how you do everything. To further your technical career, soft skills like communication, leadership, critical thinking, ownership, adaptability, and collaboration are necessary.  In this meet up, you’ll discuss and learn techniques to transform your current soft skills through discipline, habit and visualization. Cute dogs and drinks included.

title: Why Aren't We Shopping for Health Care?
speaker: David Vivero
description: In contrast to our savvy consumer ways in retail, real estate, and travel, most Americans are incredibly passive when it comes to health care, an industry that impacts not only lives but also wallets. Americans spend 16% of their annual income on health care, nearly 26 million Americans don't take their meds due to cost, and out-of-pocket health care spending continues to rise and put more people in debt. This panel will bring together diverse voices in consumer health care to discuss why people aren't doing more to research and shop for health care, as well as what’s it going to take - data, engineering, design, policy, or otherwise - to empower people to make better health care decisions.

title: Austin's Best Transportation & Mobility Startups
speaker: Joseph Kopser
description: In 60 minutes you'll learn about five of Austin's Best Transportation & Mobility Startups in a fun and fast-paced pitch session. Each entrepreneur will get five minutes to demo their solution and then they will get grilled by a panel of mobility experts. Already recognized as one of the top cities for entrepreneurs in the U.S., Austin is one home to Car2Go and has Google testing autonomous cars on our roads. Come see what everyone's so excited about! These startups are all part of the Capital Factory Accelerator. Capital Factory is Austin's center of gravity for entrepreneurs with coworking, events, classes, mentors and a unique matching investment fund.

title: Design at the Speed of Thought
speaker: Talin Wadsworth
description: Procrastination and deadlines conflict with every designer's desire to deliver a unique solution. In this revealing talk, Talin describes how during his journey as a designer he faced his fears and began to generate his ideas at the speed of thought. He will share examples of how rapid design led him to solutions he might not have even considered. Talin's session is a story of growing in your career and trusting in your intuition as a designer.

title: Designing Emotionally Intelligent Machines
speaker: Sophie Kleber
description: As artificial intelligence and machine learning seep into the mainstream, how can designers ensure the intelligent machines and services they create are more "Big Hero 6" and less "Ex Machina?" With affective computing, we can design experiences that are intelligent and empathetic. From politeness to emotional awareness, this presentation will explore how empathy is becoming an important design element in the machine reaction algorithm. Join Sophie Kleber, Executive Director of Product and Innovation at Huge, to learn how emotional intelligence and conversational UIs are humanizing brands and making personality tangible like never before. Sophie will explore whether or not we should want our machines to be empathetic, evaluate current examples of emotional computing, and frameworks that can help us design for emotional intelligence.

title: Swiping Right on Inclusivity with Tinder & GLAAD
speaker: Nick Adams
description: In 2016, Tinder worked with GLAAD, the LGBTQ media advocacy organization, to update and improve its gender identity features for the transgender and gender non-conforming communities. Today, Tinder users can break beyond the labels of "man" and "woman" by identifying with any term that best describes their gender identity. We'll discuss the reaction to Tinder's update and what this means for the future of trans people and dating.

title: Tech’s Lessons for Healthcare
speaker: Andy Tryba
description: For all of the technological challenges and bureaucratic hurdles, the most important healthcare puzzles are among the most basic: how do you get people to follow their prescriptions, show up to doctor’s appointments, or modify their homes so they can live safely in the place they want to be. Healthcare has failed to address these basic questions in a consistent, widespread way. Now other industries, especially technology-focused ones, are finding answers in the solutions, services and ideas they’ve already deployed in very different sectors. This panel will explore how inventive collaborations with Transportation Networking Companies (TNCs), Short Term Rental (STR) entities and others in the sharing economy can improve health outcomes, reduce costs, and beat healthcare companies at their own game.

title: Design+Science: Discovering Better Medicines, Faster
speaker: Christian Marc Schmidt
description: Understanding how genes influence disease is becoming a core focus for scientists designing new medicines to treat grievous illnesses. Analyzing the mountains of molecular data required to find the optimal therapy to positively impact patient’s lives is an ineffective and laborious process. To overcome these challenges scientists collaborated with a design firm to create Insight, a groundbreaking technology platform that helps scientists visualize massive sets of molecular data to more quickly find the “magic bullet molecule”.  Join us to learn from their collaboration and the process of designing Insight via a human-centered design process, including a live demonstration of the tool.

title: Basic Income: Can Giving Away Free Money Save Us?
speaker: Michael Faye
description: Should the government give everyone enough money to live on, no strings attached?  Will such a “universal basic income” become “to the 21st century what political and civil rights were to the 20th,” as India’s CEA has speculated?

title: Let’s Map: Build and Inspire a Future We All Want to Live In
speaker: Martin Wezowski
description: We talk about change, but what are the mechanics behind it, the dynamics of change? How fast is it? What it means to be an innovator and designer is transforming faster than before, from classic product definition and styling of the superficial to system design of everything, including social and political systems, deeply rooted in a space of challenges and promises between cutting edge tech and humanism. In an increasingly exponential and converging digital-fueled change, we design a relationship, a behavior, that the product will follow. This exponential change is our most important innovation brief and the stakes are high, It is just too important to be left only to designers, or any single team. Technology is the human evolution this gives a new playground for “Human centered “, I call it the Humachine, a symbiosis between human creativity and empathy and machine intelligence, this opens new worlds for creatives in any occupation. I believe that everything can and should be given a purpose through innovation and design, including the innovation systems themselves. Let’s open our minds with some examples of change and a couple of visons that might just become true, if we want to.

title: Bringing Web Technology to Feature Animation
speaker: Mike H Mahony
description: Discover the unique - and sometimes surprising - technology solutions Pixar employs behind the scenes. Senior software engineer Mike Mahony shines a light on the unique intersection of web tech, devOps, and feature animation. Discover how our team of engineers combat legacy code, shrinking time-tables, growing deliverables, and film-specific requirements throughout the image mastering and localization phases of the production pipeline.

title: SXSW Release It Round 2
speaker: Trey Bowles
description: SXSW Release It is a special pitch competition in Startup Village on the opening day of the SXSW Conference. Ten cutting-edge companies launching a new product or service during this SXSW season will present to a panel of judges comprised of technology industry experts, venture capitalists, and high-profile media. The winner will then be chosen based on which product or service is most likely to succeed in the marketplace.

title: The Intersection of Personality & Business Meet Up
speaker: Amelia Smith
description:
People are the greatest asset to any organization, but they’re also the most complex to manage and support. Employees no longer expect work and a pension—they expect fulfillment and purpose.  And fulfillment is not a one-size-fits-all solution. What motivates one person is different from the rest.
In this meet up designed for entrepreneurs, team leaders, team members, peacekeepers, and psychology-enthusiasts, we’ll explore some key elements of personality plus how you can drive retention, encourage thought diversity, and  build mutual understanding when personalities clash in the workplace.
Bring stories to share, and we’ll discuss some simple strategies for developing greater awareness of the unique personalities on your team, how to bolster their strengths, and where to watch out.

title: Richard Garriott’s “Explore/Create”
speaker: Richard Garriott de Cayeux
description: Entrepreneur, explorer, and gaming icon Richard “Lord British” Garriott has been behind some of the most exciting undertakings of our time. A founding father of the video game industry, Richard coined the term "avatar", created the entire genre of the massively-multiplayer online role-playing games (MMORPGs), and authored the famed “Ultima” series. Richard has also been one of the foremost pioneers of the private space industry. He founded Space Adventures, the only company to arrange spaceflights for private citizens and in 2008, Richard became the first American second-generation astronaut when he flew on Soyuz TMA-13 to the International Space Station. Join Richard as he shares stories from his new memoir “Explore/Create” – and tells tales found nowhere in print.

title: Miso Soup & Prototyping: The Future of Advertising
speaker: Jutaro Mochizuki
description: As a digital production company within a Tokyo-based ad agency group, we’ve cultivated our unique style to ‘ferment’ new digital technologies that can be utilized for marketers to deliver the true value of their products or services, and enhance consumers’ everyday lives.

title: Unsportsmanlike Conduct: Football & Sexual Assault
speaker: Jessica Luther
description: In Unsportsmanlike Conduct, Jessica Luther writes about the playbook coaches, teams, universities, communities, the NCAA, the media, and fans seem to follow whenever a college football player is accused of sexual assault. If everyone runs their play well, scrutiny dies down quickly, no institution ever has to change how it operates, and the evaporation of these cases into nothingness looks natural. After Luther unpacks this societal playbook piece by piece, and advocates that we destroy the old plays, she then suggests we replace them with ones that will force us to finally do something about this issue. It’s a book about what is but also one about what could be.

title: Latinas in Tech Meet Up
speaker: Susana Meza
description: Women may make up the majority of online users, trendsetters, and consumers, but we have a long way to go to reach proportionate amounts in the field of technology. Hispanics are the fastest-growing segment of the U.S. population, and they represent a largely untapped source of technical talent. Women hold only 26% of technology positions and Latinas only 2%. An influx of Latinas into technical fields can help to inspire ingenuity, to accelerate productivity, and improve how people interact with technology. This meet up will help build community and a sense of belonging, allowing us to leverage each other’s knowledge to continue to innovate and promote more Latinas in Tech!

title: Leveraging Social Media to Build Your Brand
speaker: Sara Dietschy
description: Have you ever wanted to use social media to help grow your brand but weren’t sure which app to use or how best to use it? In this session filmmaker and YouTube creator Sara Dietschy will give an overview of multiple social media platforms including tips on when and how to use each one as well as talking about how she grew YouTube channel from 4,000 to 100,000 subscribers in just a month.

title: Art in Tech and Social Media Meet Up
speaker: Heather Sparks
description: With +37k #artselfie hashtags on Instagram, it’s clear social media has morphed the art experience. But how will art mutate social media and tech? Starting with Amalia Ulman's 2014 “Excellences and Perfections” on Instagram, we know the distinction between art and content is now unclear. With the formation of the +ArtApp collective, petitioning for an “Art” category in Apple's App Store, it's obvious art can push tech in new directions. This session gathers people interested in the future of art in tech and social media. How will art influence tech and social media? Let's discuss!

title: SXSW Eco Startup Speed Pitches
speaker: Karl Popham

title: Working with Giants
speaker: Christy Abizaid
description: Innovation isn't just happening in garages in Silicon Valley, it's happening all over the world in coffee shops, spare bedrooms, and co-working spaces. How can the largest companies in the world tap into this groundswell of innovation and combat the Innovator's Dilemma?

title: Convergence Keynote: Cory Richards
speaker: Cory Richards
description: A climber and visual storyteller, Cory Richards was named National Geographic Adventurer of the Year (2012) and a National Geographic Fellow (2015). His photography has appeared in National Geographic Magazine, Outside Magazine, Man of the World, and The New York Times.

title: SA2020's Digital Dashboard of Progress
speaker: Molly Cox
description: Molly Cox, President and CEO of SA2020, will lead a discussion on how San Antonio has taken a comprehensive plan for progression and dialed it into 58 digital indicators. Cox will discuss the community process for deriving the indicators as well as the technology required to monitor and update the date in real time to influence and monitor real change.

title: Design Changes the World, Adobe XD Changes Design
speaker: Tomas Krcha
description: Go behind the scenes of making Adobe Experience Design CC (Beta) with one of its earliest creators, Senior Product Manager Tom Krcha. Tom will share the product principles that serve as the foundation for Adobe XD and how they guide the team’s thinking for the near term and the future.

title: Rapid Medical Device Innovation Meet Up
speaker: Marcel Botha
description: Accelerating innovation is often as simple as creating new intersections. For medicine, a historically closed community with a huge disparity between advanced device verticals, like those used in oncology, or various primary care devices created mid-century, it's hard to know where to start. 10XBeta has been bringing together doctor inventors, medical students, designers and engineers to expedite the innovation process and unlock solutions to the most complex problems. Come discuss teaching design thinking to doctors, creating platforms for new types of innovation, and creating new funding structures for device acceleration.

title: The Colors of Design Cultures
speaker: Kit Oliynyk
description: Calling people “UX ninjas” and “UI gurus” is easy. Building design culture at large scale is hard. All designers are different; we have unique skillsets and personalities. It’s vital for design leaders to help designers grow and evolve professionally, while partnering them in a meaningful way to complement each other’s strengths. This session is about how Capital ONE Design is doing this, how they are making design talent assessments that don’t make people shoot themselves, and the framework that’s guiding them along the way. P.S. If you’re a Magic nerd, you’re so gonna love this!

title: The Most Epic Board Game Ever Meet Up
speaker: Jennifer Noinaj
description: Casual board gamer? Interested but never learned? Or can’t live without your Catan? Come to this meet up where new and experienced board gamers can mingle, play board games, and make some new connections before SXSW gaming starts. We will have a variety of board games on hand to play as well as recommendations for games that work well 1-on-1, for groups, quick games to play during lunch, and more.

title: All Mentors Are != Created Equal Meet Up
speaker: Lori Culberson
description: The vast number of students enrolling in code schools increases the need for patient and knowledgeable mentors. Many senior developers who wish to mentor others believe that since they are good at building software, they will also be good at mentoring students. That assumption may be false. This session aims to turn code ninjas into great mentors by introducing effective methodologies used in the most high performing K-12 classrooms. It will cover techniques such as how to assess a mentee’s learning style, how to check for understanding, and believe it or not, why it is important to avoid sarcasm.

title: Office Politics: Dealing With Conflict at Work
speaker: Amy Gallo
description: Whether you enjoy a lively debate or prefer to suppress your feelings over disagreements, we all struggle with conflicts at work. Every day we navigate an office full of competing interests, clashing personalities, limited time and resources, and fragile egos. In this session, Harvard Business Review editor, Amy Gallo, author of the new book, The HBR Guide to Dealing with Conflict at Work will discuss tactics to address conflict professionally and productively and in a way that improves both your work and your relationships.

title: You Can Survive Creative Burnout Meet Up
speaker: Selena Lounds
description: We’ve all been there – when we’re convinced everything we make is crap, when the things we love become the things we hate, when what once had us jumping out of bed in the morning finds us endlessly pressing the snooze button. It happens to the best of us… Creative Burnout. How do you identify it? What are the signs? How do you reignite the passion? In this session we’ll discuss how to avoid, identify and survive creative burnout, because everything you make is not crap.

title: PIVOT: The Only Move That Matters is Your Next One
speaker: Jenny Blake
description: No matter your age, life stage, bank account balance, or career level, you can learn how to pivot strategically into your next opportunity or grow within your current role. By doubling down on what is already working, you can cut through confusion and move more quickly in a new direction. Pivoting is a mindset and a skill set, and it is one we can all get better at. This interactive session (and book signing) will resonate with anyone facing the question of what comes next by providing an overview of the four-stage Pivot Method, a strategic process you can cycle through as many times as necessary.

title: Creating Space for Making in the Workplace
speaker: Alexandra Jane Williams
description:
Companies around the world are creating room for physical making in the workplace, for employees to get their hands dirty with screen printing, woodworking, circuitry, and more. But what does physical making have to do with building better products? Are these spaces a distraction or can they have a lasting impact on business and culture?
This panel brings together creatives from Pinterest, Nike, and IBM, to discuss how spaces like this come to be, why they exist, and how they're changing the modern workplace.

title: Health IT Developer Meet Up
speaker: Ashish Patel
description: A meet up for Health IT developers, investors, and enthusiasts hosted by Health IT rockstar Fred Trotter (CareSet and DocGraph). If you are intrigued by quantified self, medical devices, electronic health records, health information exchange, meaningful use, macra, health apps, or any other Health IT buzz word, this meet up is for you. Please bring a “Twitter introduction" of yourself so we can meet you quickly. Expect to leave with a map of all of the top talks at SXSW on health, healthcare, or health technology.

title: Design Intelligently for Artificial Intelligence
speaker: Ido Mor
description: Discussions around AI tend to focus on how powerful the technology is. What’s missing from the discourse are principles for how to make interaction with AI feel more intuitively human. How should engagement differ by channel & occasion? What are the pros and cons of using voice vs. text vs. image to communicate with AI? In this workshop we will introduce a framework defining these best practices and how to deploy them to super-charge the AI-powered experiences you’re creating.

title: The Future of Experience Design
speaker: Eric Snowden
description: What's next? How will design evolve? Eric Snowden, Senior Director of Design at Adobe, provides a glimpse into how he and his team plan for the next generation of design and designers, how design’s role in the industry is evolving and what trends are going to change design in the near future.

title: LGBT Community Driving Digital Health Innovations
speaker: Scout
description: The LGBT community has been the earliest adopters of technology, and in the last few years, we've seen tech-savvy consumers transform into trailblazing entrepreneurs. From introducing new modalities for STI testing and treatment to HIV prevention research and education, digital health innovators have leveraged technology to solve the problems that exist within its community.  The inclusiveness of the LGBT community has given it an early mover advantage, and this panel will discuss how the characteristics of this community can be a beacon for diversity in technology.

title: Start2Meet: Speed Networking for Startups Meet Up
speaker: Caroline Andreis
description: For years, the speed dating concept was used to stimulate people to meet new people with one purpose: matchmaking. We believe in a different way to explore this concept: encouraging startups to meet investors and agencies at SXSW 2017. Rather than a panel where we would talk to an audience, we’re going to invite the audience to try a networking experience which we call Start2Meet. In a room, we’re going to make a layout, always placing two chairs in front of each other. In one line of chairs, only startups and independent developers. In the other, investors and agencies. There'll be three minutes chats rounds until everyone has met. At the end, we’re going to ask people to share their impressions.

title: Growing Tech in a Developing World
speaker: Kaan Akin
description: Startups and disruption of the markets has been hottest keywords in business and techspace for long time. Unfortunately while founding and running my own accelerator Hackquarters in Istanbul, we have stumbled upon many different problems where people don't face in States or some of European countries and that requires different approach to solve. I'll talk about the major differences in the development of the markets and current status of the development. And we'll point out, how other countries might embrace the idea as well.

title: Improv(e) Your Pitch Presence, Poise and Connection
speaker: Amira Pollock
organization: The University of Texas at Austin
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Atlas Obscura: Exploring the World’s Hidden Wonders
speaker: Ella Morton
description: Morton will offer insights into finding, navigating to, and exploring the hidden and unusual places that exist all around us. Along the way, she’ll share the most astonishing off-the-beaten path wonders she discovered while writing the book—from the synchronized fireflies of Kuala Lumpur, to the world’s deepest places, incredible natural phenomena, lost cities, self-made castles, lake monsters, unusual museums, and much more. Offering a breath of fresh air in today’s Google-mapped world, where it can often feel as though everything has already been discovered, Morton will prove that there are still magical places to discover behind every corner—if you just know where to look.

title: Makers, Etsy-ers, and DIYers Meet Up
speaker: Jordan Elkins
description: This Meet Up is geared towards all those who find joy in creating, designing, and experimenting with clothing, jewelry, decor, and much much more.  Whether you're just starting out, or have been a maker your entire life please attend.  We will discuss the various techniques and platforms used to create and market your brand and inventions.  If you like to work with your hands to craft unique items, this Meet Up is for you!

title: Humans, Robots + Microbes: The Challenge of Mars
speaker: Monsi Roman
description: Getting to Mars and thriving there will take a lot of technology and a community of ideas. Humanoid robots that can work side-by-side with astronauts. Lab-created organs that could mitigate the health risks for humans in deep space. Microbes that can enhance off-Earth life support systems. Many of these innovations have deep roots in science fiction, and now have the potential to become science reality. NASA technology experts and Hollywood come together to discuss how dreams can go from screen to space.

title: To Build in Health, Follow the $, Not the Patient
speaker: Andrew Rosenthal
description: Starting anything new is hard. Especially in healthcare. With a complex, regulated, multi-sided market, traditional experience-led business design can lead to abject, expensive failure. Customer discovery and following the flow of dollars is critical. But not easy. Hear from founders, funders & advisors about business design in healthcare. Examples are drawn from companies that deliver health services, take on financial risk, analyze care & provide data tooling. Learn from panelists' experiences: hundreds of millions of dollars in venture money raised and spent, millions of users engaged, Presidential-level policy initiatives, and a litany of failures as well.

title: Mentor Session: Corry Robb
speaker: Corry Robb
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Finland: The Hotbed of Technology and Startups
speaker: Hartti Suomela
description:
Finland has strong background in mobile technology and ICT, but recently Finland has made inroads in many other industries, like games (e.g. Clash of Clans, Angry Birds), health & wellbeing (e.g. wearable heart rate monitors) and Cleantech. 
This session investigates the Finnish Technology ecosystem, ranging from VC-funded startups to possibilities for bigger foreign companies to transfer R&D functions to Finland (Foreign Direct Investments). We will also investigate the reasons behind recent emergence of startups in Finland. Finnish society is highly supportive of entrepreneurship, with a flourishing Silicon Valley-inspired business culture. Wired listed Finland as one of the best countries for start-ups and the annual Slush start-up event in Helsinki is among the largest in the world.

title: When Your Internet Things Know How You Feel
speaker: Pamela Pavliscak
description: The technology we use every day knows a lot about what we do—what we click on, where we go, and who we follow. But so far, it doesn’t know much about how we feel. That’s changing.

title: Sound Like a Programmatic Pro and Act Like One Too
speaker: Clare Hanson
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Get a Warrant: The 4th Amendment and Digital Data
speaker: Mike Godwin
description: Cellphone location data, troves of communication metadata, old emails, even license plates and images of citizens stored in databases: The digital era has brought about a drastic increase in the amount of info authorities are collecting while bypassing the limits on unwarranted search and seizure in the Fourth Amendment of the Constitution. In July 2016, a bipartisan pack of congressional lawmakers organized the Fourth Amendment Caucus to work legislatively to restore privacy protections from government intrusion in the digital age. This panel will focus on efforts to craft laws to solve these problems and the challenges that caucus members (and all digital privacy activists) face.

title: Mentor Session: Lauran Driver
speaker: Lauran Driver
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Harnessing Today’s Innovation Culture for Uncle Sam
speaker: Brandon Tseng
description: From autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence, and machine learning to  cybersecurity, VR, and space 3.0, startups are making leaps and bounds, creating technology that is often valuable in both civilian and defense contexts. Unfortunately,  many of these companies are weary of pursuing business with the federal government because of traditionally inflexible terms and conditions and long drawn out processes.  Clearly, the government must adapt its way of doing business to harness the strategic advantage inherent in the innovation ecosystems across the country. Through Defense Innovation Unit Experimental (DIUx) - a unit focused on accelerating commercial innovation into the hands of our men and women in uniform — the Department of Defense (DoD) is working to make doing business with DoD fast, flexible, and collaborative.  This panel will host those who have served on the front-lines as well as tech industry insiders to discuss the DIUx model and how startups can meaningfully contribute to our national defense.

title: Crave Build-A-Vibrator Workshop Group 1
speaker: Christine Concho
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Product Managers Meet Up
speaker: Vince Maniago
description: Buried in Brainstorms? Puzzled by Priorities? Stuck in Scrum? What is it that Product Managers do all day, anyway? Let's get together and discuss this rarely broached topic and how to bridge the gap in organizations big and small.

title: Unprecedented: The Election That Changed Everything
speaker: Ana Marie Cox
description: In this past year we have witnessed a change in the way campaigns and elections are run in America. With two very polarizing candidates and countless scandals, the electorate struggled to find ease with a decision of vital importance to the direction of the nation. Now that the people have spoken, resulting in an unexpected victory for Donald Trump, Americans are left to consider the election in all its unprecedented and historical significance and what it will mean for American democracy and elections to come.  Join CNN's Jake Tapper for discussion and reflection on the completion of an American election that has been like no other and what lies ahead for the future of journalism and media.

title: Mentor Session: Jessica Santana
speaker: Jessica Santana
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Mentor Session Rebecca Liebman
speaker: Rebecca Liebman
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Mentor Session: Nancy Giordano
speaker: Nancy Giordano
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: One Nation Under Stress: How Social Connection Can Heal Us
speaker: Vivek Murthy
description: Stress. There is the good kind, the kind that makes us feel alive and excited. And then there is chronic stress, the type of stress that keeps our cortisol levels high and has a toxic effect on our bodies, minds, and hearts. With 24% of adults in America reported experiencing extreme stress, our country is feeling more stressed than ever. In a world that feels increasingly fraught and fractured, how might we heal ourselves? Join in conversation with Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, 19th U.S. Surgeon General, doctor, and tech entrepreneur, on how cultivating emotional well-being can counter stress. And how social connection might be the best prescription not only for ourselves but for the future of our country.

title: Build a Chatbot: The New Consumer Engagement Tool
speaker: Tricia Katz
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Instrumenting Startup Customer Acquisition
speaker: Michael Discenza
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Diversity-Friendly Software
speaker: Jon Pincus
description: It’s time for software to embrace differences (not just tolerate them), and see diversity as a strength. Most software today works best for people like the teams that create it, and embeds biases against women, African-Americans, Latinxs, LGBTAIQs, people with disabilities, and other marginalized groups - and it's even worse at the intersections.  So the industry is primed for change. This session discusses current examples, “best practices” that teams can immediately leverage, and emerging ideas from projects that have focused heavily on diversity.  We also discuss the challenges and how to overcome them - and chart a path to the future.

title: Innovation in Cuba: The Rise of Azúcar Valley
speaker: Mara Abrams
description: A warming of relations between the U.S. and Cuba has led to an unprecedented level of dialogue. Much of the conversation has centered around tourism, but there’s a deeper opportunity to connect with a new wave of Cuban entrepreneurs solving uniquely Cuban problems. As part of diplomatic trip with the Aspen Institute and the Richardson Center, a group of U.S. entrepreneurs met with Cuban startups to get a better sense of their challenges. Common themes emerged: lack of connectivity, business training, and mentorship.

title: A Tale of Murder: Why Netflix Killed Max
speaker: Sam Horner
description: Would you ever kill something you created? At Netflix, every new feature is rigorously tested before they release it to the general public. Meet Max, Netflix’s talking concierge service who was successful in testing, had significant time and financial investment, but still met his demise two and half years after his creation. So why did Netflix decide to kill him rather than release him to their 85+ million members worldwide? In this session, Sam Horner will share learnings from Max and a number of Netflix design projects. He will discuss how to evaluate a project’s success or failure and how this influences whether to pursue the idea further, or to kill something you are highly invested in.

title: Mentor Session: Larissa Meek
speaker: Larissa Meek
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: How to Be an Ally
speaker: Tiffany Puett
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Eyes In The Sky: The Future of AI and Satellites
speaker: Harrison Wallace
description: The geospatial industry is producing petabytes of data from satellites, sensors, drones, and other gauges. One company (Spaceknow) is building an AI system that will process this kind of data in meaningful ways. It will scan, understand, and narrate daily activities of us – all seven billion us. This will fundamentally change the way we view, relate to, and understand planet Earth. Many other companies will follow, much to the chagrin of world goverments. Will there be anywhere to hide from the Eyes in the Sky?

title: Toward a More Personalized Web
speaker: Heather Brunner
description: It’s about time websites got smart. Today’s web experiences treat customers as if they are all the same. The trouble is - we all want to be treated like the individuals that we are and we want our time on site to be as efficient as possible. As a loyal customer, we want to be recognized; we want our habits to be anticipated; we want to be delighted and we want our experiences to improve with every visit. Moreover, the signal to noise ratio with information is oftentimes overwhelming. This all needs to shift - the websites of the future will thrive by making relevant information find the user, as opposed to the user having to find the information relevant to them. In this talk, WP Engine CEO Heather Brunner divulges how marketers and the tech community can help the web tech get personal.

title: Can Affinity Investing Solve the Startup Bias?
speaker: Paul Grossinger
description: Studies show that race, gender and orientation have an impact on the ability of a start-up to get funded and how much funding it will receive. Increasingly, affinity investors provide investment, networks and business guidance to founders based on a personal affinity (e.g., minority community, alma mater, gender, LGBT, etc.). Given the growing reliance on early stage investors for support from money to mentorship, we’ll look at how affinity investors play an ever larger role in supporting founders who would otherwise be outside the mainstream, including the case for affinity investing and how it provides a successful model for the future of angel investing.

title: Trust Your Gut: Can Biomes Change Science Forever?
speaker: Jack Gilbert
description: Did you know that the trillions of microbes that live in and on you, communicate with each other and interact with everything you encounter, seen and unseen?  We are just starting to understand the incredibly important role this “biological dark matter” plays in our health and systems — sometimes with consequences not seen for a decade or more.  Scientists all over the world say that microbiomes could potentially change everything we know about health and healthcare: Mapping our biomes is a science challenge, a data challenge, and a human challenge. Join us to discover the latest and get ahead of the trend.

title: Mentor Session: Andrew Ruegger
speaker: Andrew Ruegger
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: True Inclusion: Leading Through World Trauma
speaker: Lisa Lee
description: On the heels of the high-profile police killings of Alton Sterling and Philando Castile, and just a day before five officers were gunned down in Dallas, Fortune published an article on “Why Employers Need to Talk about the Police Shootings of Black People.” The piece circulated in offices around the country, especially throughout Silicon Valley, where some employees were reportedly “calling in black” as self care during these trying times. In this moment of challenge and change, companies need to lead with compassion, especially in an industry that lacks diverse perspectives. In addition, we will examine how companies can mobilize management so they are prepared to lead in inclusive ways.

title: A Cross-Country Journey of Rapid Creation
speaker: Craig Winslow
description: In May 2015, Craig Winslow, a new Adobe Creative Resident, had an idea to travel with a friend across the United States to create individual light installations in 15 cities. The goal was to reflect on their feelings/struggles in moving away from family and friends in pursuit of career, and to create a narrative-driven animation that unfolded live to backers, without preplanning the story or locations. After successfully funding the project through Kickstarter, they set off to create one new artistic light installation every day. Join Craig as he discusses how this cross-country adventure changed his design mentality, sparked creative inspiration, and fueled his creative energy.

title: Aussies at SXSW Meet Up
speaker: Ben Keenan
description: Calling all makers, doers, start-uppers, techs and creatives from the land down under (and Hell, even Kiwis!)! We are here representing our innovative ventures in Austin, the epicentre of new ideas and technology, and it's high time we compared notes, mates!

title: Mentor Session: John Colucci
speaker: John Colucci
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Disrupted: Ending Bro Culture and Bias in Startup-Land
speaker: Dan Lyons
organization: Disrupted: My Misadventures In The Start-Up Bubble
description: The past decade has produced an explosion in billion-dollar “unicorns.” These new companies have brought tremendous innovation, but also a great deal of dysfunction, especially in the way they treat employees. An industry that prides itself on being progressive has in many ways moved backward, eroding a century of progress in worker rights. Bro culture, bias, and stress have become hallmarks of this new workplace.

title: How the Dept. of Energy Fuels Cleantech Innovation
speaker: Jackie Kerby Moore
description: The US national laboratories are a valuable resource for cleantech businesses across all sectors, offering world class research and innovative programs that rapidly accelerate the pace of innovation. Join a group of entrepreneurs and startups as they share how and where you can access DOE investigators, facilities, technology, and more. This panel discusses the Small Business Vouchers pilot, Cyclotron Road, Lab-Corps and other programs that put national laboratory resources at your fingertips.

title: National Strategy for Transportation Data
speaker: Ariel Gold
description: The transportation revolution is coming. Connected vehicles are already talking to each other and to the infrastructure around them. Smart cities are embracing the promise of connected technologies to improve safety, mobility, and sustainability for their citizens. Once deployed nationwide, these technologies will produce massive amounts of data. What new businesses, public services, and research could these data fuel? What should the Federal role be in enabling nationwide access to the data while protecting the privacy of travelers? Join the conversation and help shape the future of transportation!

title: Dawn of the Drones
speaker: Gretchen West
description:
The day has finally come and the floodgates are open! The FAA has broadly authorized businesses to use drones without having to jump through costly, lengthy regulatory hoops. We’re on the ground floor of the most exciting commercial industry disruption in recently technological history.
But do our current policies go far enough to be valuable across a broad spectrum of businesses? And what does the prospect of commercial drones filling the airways mean for the public? 
I’ll talk about what still needs to be done to truly open the US for commercial drones; how we maintain our competitive advantage; and what we can do to enjoy all the benefits drones provide.

title: How Tech & Innovation Can Cure Health Politics
speaker: Clay Johnston
organization: Dell Medical School at UT Austin
description: For generations, healthcare has been driven by government, shaped by politics and primed for disruption. Now, technological advancement has opened the door to transformational opportunities, imperatives, and leaders who are asking fresh questions and finding answers by drawing on diverse skill sets. Observing the forces that reshaped other industries and the economy as a whole, innovators from tech and elsewhere are drawing new maps toward commonly held objectives such as better health outcomes, lower costs and reduced disparities – and their ideas are redefining what it means to be patient and healer. In this conversation, Peter Orszag – President Obama’s Director of the Office of Management and Budget through the passage of the Affordable Care Act and now Vice Chairman of investment banking, Managing Director and Global Co-Head of Healthcare at Lazard – will discuss transformations now buffeting the industry and the roles that the public and private sector will need to play going forward.

title: How Craft, Culinary and Culture Collided
speaker: Hugh Daschbach
description: Pearl is a culinary and cultural destination in San Antonio. As a dynamic and evolving environment, Pearl is committed to stewardship and learning. At the most southern end of the Pearl is the newly redeveloped 19th century brewery called Hotel Emma. Hugh Daschbach will discuss how this redevelopment was the perfect opportunity for culinary, craft and culture to collide in San Antonio. Daschbach will discuss the process of redevelopment, through design to execution of the vision that was Hotel Emma.

title: Bot Meet Up
speaker: Michael Brown
description: Is this the year of the chatbot? Google, Apple, Facebook, Microsoft and Amazon - just to name a few - believe that bots will be a big part of our future. Join us at this casual Meet Up to network with other attendees, from industry leaders to beginners, who are curious about the current bot landscape and what’s next.

title: Activism, Allyship and Where We Go from Here
speaker: Aminatou Sow
description: Cecile Richards is president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America and Planned Parenthood Action Fund. David Karp is the founder and CEO of Tumblr, a platform home to more than 300 million creators, and also a board member of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

title: Draw to Win: Innovate With Your Visual Mind
speaker: Dan Roam
description: Ninety percent of all information transmitted today is visual. If you want to be in the conversation, you need to be visual too. The problem? Drawing, visual logic, and spatial communication aren't taught in the schools that most businesspeople, entrepreneurs, and technology people attend. The solution? This little book describes the Ten Commandments of visual thinking: how to use your visual mind to lead, sell, and innovate.

title: Crave Build-A-Vibrator Workshop Group 2
speaker: Christine Concho
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.”

title: Community Management Meet Up
speaker: Audrey Lo
description: The Community Management (CM) industry is becoming a recognized force within companies. This meet up will dive into how and why you should hire a Community Manager, where they live on the organization chart, how CM's work cross from startup phase to hyper-growth to established teams, and how to set goals and metrics across the phases. Community Managers, Marketing Executives and CEOs will learn what it takes to build a strong foundation for an effective community program within their organizations - from building an Ambassador Program to building grassroots movements and scaling across cities.

title: Mentor Session: Michelle Tripp
speaker: Michelle Tripp
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: The Real Future of Self-Driving Cars
speaker: George Hotz
description: We are comma.ai. Last year, after a skirmish with regulators, we made available open source software that can retrofit old cars with knock off Tesla Autopilot. This year, the growth begins. We look at how the industry will play out, who the players will be, and who the jokers are. We will also shamelessly shill for our dashcam apps. And if the next few months go according to plan, we'll announce our novel Self-Driving Car business model everyone will be itching to copy. This is not fake news.

title: #OffCuba
speaker: Leon Krauze
description: The world is more offline than you think; therefore, Cuban Solutions, which are different from what you can find on the Internet, are very useful. In #OffCuba will be shared how Cuban offline technology is developed. Cuban entrepreneurs have achieved a lot of experience creating offline apps and platforms that can be exported and used in airplanes, buses, cruise liners and areas without full Internet access. This will be an opportunity to showcase Cuban offline technology to the world and invite all possible friends to the country

title: Empowering a Billion Women by 2020
speaker: Ingrid Vanderveldt
description: EBW is “changing the world by changing the ratio” with data driven solutions in industries that create economic and social impact for women and girls across industries and borders. Additionally, and with the help of our partners, ultimately reaching our goal of Empowering a Billion Women by 2020.  In 2017 we will be leveraging our access, collection and analysis of women owned businesses worldwide to release The EBW Economic Data Platform and EBW Global Economic Reports on Women’s Entrepreneurship to bridge and accelerate the mutual investments between global brands and women entrepreneurs they seek to connect and do business with.

title: Using Design & Tech to Create a Healthy Community
speaker: Jennifer Chenoweth
