description: Helping individuals, as part of a community, to truly engage with their health requires a holistic rethink of the tired, ineffective mechanisms we’ve employed for decades. That’s the goal of an ambitious Austin collaboration between five unlikely partners:  the Design Institute for Health at UT Austin, Jennifer Chenoweth (a celebrated Austin artist), the Thinkery (a unique children's museum), ThinkEAST (a new residential district for the creative community), and Johnson & Johnson (the multinational health care company). This team is creating new approaches — technological and otherwise — to improving health in a planned East Austin community, using a creative process that combines visual arts, learning and exhibit design, as well as new approaches to data visualization. This conversation will feature four of the collaborators discussing their unprecedented effort to raise a community's health consciousness and literacy, to empower and enable them to act on their own behalf, to develop new insights into the priorities of residents, and ultimately to create offerings that have significant impact on their collective health.

title: Accessibility: Why It’s So Important
speaker: Larry Goldberg
description: Accessibility is all about ensuring applications are easy to use for everyone—including persons with disabilities. It's the Right Thing To Do, and simple awareness is one of the largest problems. Better accessibility results in better design, better code, better products, and better user experiences. Excellence requires inclusion during all stages of the software development life-cycle. We will make a compelling case to solidify accessibility as a staple of design, development, and product management; we hope it will inspire everyone to make accessibility a priority.

title: The Caribbean: The Up and Coming Tech Melting Pot
speaker: Christine Souffrant Ntim
description:
The Caribbean is an often overlooked region when it comes to tech and innovation. This is where an enormous amount of opportunities lie. The Governments of various Caribbean islands are looking to innovate and are setting up programs and handing out grants to attract startups and tech companies. They are working on policies and looking into closing partnerships to stimulate this. A group of ambassadors from varius islands of the Caribbean are living proof that the Caribbean is up and coming and shouldn’t be overlooked anymore. 
Everything ATECH does evolves around the creation of a local startup tech sector and promoting Aruba and the Caribbean as a global tech hub. A place where global startups, and both local and international entrepreneurs, can build companies, test new concepts and receive guidance and funding. Further, a thriving entrepreneurial sector initially catalyzed by the private sector will have a strong foundation as it limits bureaucracy and politics. The government’s role should be one of a facilitator. 
Technological innovation is a powerful source of productivity and growth, especially when bourne by startups. 
Why now?
We have witnessed firsthand the birth of a mini revolution, where young entrepreneurs have decided to take action instead of relying on the government or other established institutions to facilitate an innovative initiative. This phenomenon is rare in Aruban and Caribbean culture. There is great momentum and this creative energy needs to be fueled to drive the machine forward and build a community of entrepreneurs that TRUST that we have their best interests at heart.
The future of our economy is going to depend on our teachings and facilitating our young people to build companies, export and encouraging them to pay it forward by teaching and helping their younger peers. 
A startup tech ecosystem has the potential to contribute to the GDP of the Caribbean economy, create new and exciting jobs, limit brain drain, stimulate established companies to be creative and innovative, to collaborate with young entrepreneurs, and products and services for export. All this and we have yet taken into account the spin-off effect it will have.

title: Web of Innovation: Science and Tech Meet Up
speaker: Stephen Mock
description: Developers interested in using your powers for good? Scientists looking to learn new technologies? Come mix it up with fellow developers, researchers, technologists and scientists for an hour of brainstorming and networking! Let’s discuss some of the new and exciting citizen science projects out there, learn about software carpentry projects that help scientists learn and leverage software skills.

title: The Accidental Entrepreneur
speaker: Bria Woods
description: What problem are you trying to solve? The first question every entrepreneur is asked at the start of pitch. Bria Woods, our accidental entrepreneur, suffered what so many young adults and college students suffer when it comes to night life and public safety. Come hear the story and see how, life experiences can turn even the most unlikely candidate into a relevant and fast past global tech entrepreneur.

title: How Innovation is Better in Africa
speaker: Toby Shapshak
description: Africa's unique problems have resulted in a unique brand of innovation out of necessity, often using mobile phones. Because we have real problems, the only way to solve them is by ourselves. More people in Africa have a phone than access to electricity (500m), but so to do 1.5bn people globally. These are the same problems the world is facing, so when we solve them, we do it for everyone. Africa's innovative spirit has produced mobile payments like M-Pesa (through which 40% of Kenya's GDP is transacted) and other ground-breaking innovations like M-Kopa, WeFarm and BRCK. We Africans are world leaders in frugal innovation. Africa is not just mobile-first, it is a mobile-only continent.

title: Mentor Session: Erin Albert
speaker: Erin Albert
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: America's Mayors: Holding the Line
speaker: Emily Ramshaw
description: Mayors may be the last line to defend progress in the face of a regressive agenda that challenges cities on immigration, health care, criminal justice reforms, civil rights, LGBT rights, funding for social programs, and more.  Their cities are finding themselves increasingly in the crosshairs of federal, and in some cases also state, leadership looking to strip away the policies and initiatives of their locally elected leaders. What constitutes “liberty” may depend on the eye of the officeholder. Hear from mayors who are on the frontlines fighting to ensure their cities continue to be the engines of economic growth, innovation, livability, and progress for the country.

title: Mentor Session: Chelsea Collier
speaker: Chelsea Collier
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Millennials at Work Meet Up
speaker: Maggie Jo Buchanan
description:
Contrary to popular opinion, research shows what motivates a millennial at work is largely the same as what motivates workers of all ages (yes, even Baby Boomers). But for many young adults across the country, the impact of the Great Recession—such as the elimination of entry-level jobs and training opportunities, and wages that failed to increase to pre-recession levels as quickly as older workers’—still resonates in ways from which other generations have been shielded.
The word “millennial” may be a favorite buzzword for the media, but join our meet up to discuss the actual, everyday experiences of the millennial worker in order to move past stereotypes and understand what young workers really value in a job.

title: Mentor Session: Neetal Parekh
speaker: Neetal Parekh
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Design Sprints: Solving Design/UX Problems Fast
speaker: Adam Perlis
description: When you think about design you generally think about the aesthetics - colors, pixels, fonts, etc. What if design took a more holistic approach? In this talk you will learn that design is much more than that and how it can transform your company. You will learn to run Design Sprints solving user experience problems by Designing, Prototyping and Testing products and processes in just 5 days. You will discover how Design Sprints can foster collaboration, establish "buy in" from your key stakeholders, and get your team to build things better, faster and cheaper. Unlock your newest competitive advantage with Design Sprints.

speaker: Arnaud Auger

speaker: Patrick Givens

title: Are Biometrics the New Face of Surveillance?
speaker: Christopher Piehota
description: Advanced biometric technology is starting to track us everywhere we go. Airports are experimenting with using iris scans as boarding passes. Credit card companies want your selfie or heartbeat to authorize digital payments. And the FBI wants to create the world's largest and most efficient electronic repository of biometric information to help track criminals, replete with iris scans and palm prints. What are the privacy implications of technology that, quite literally, never forgets a face? Will increasingly sophisticated biometric tracking make society safer and daily life more convenient – or will it usher in a new era of surveillance?

title: Making Law on Mars
speaker: Berin Szoka
description: Say you wanted to build a legal system from scratch. How would you do it? As humans venture into the solar system to colonize new planets, far from any existing government, that question is going to present itself in dramatic new ways. And while Martian colonies may be a ways off, the question is already confronting experts and governments here on planet Earth, thanks to innovations like seasteading and charter cities. In this session, experts will examine the challenges of creating new legal regimes from scratch and discuss how competitive governance and rapid innovation can help improve legal systems new and old.

title: The Messy Truth with Van Jones
speaker: Van Jones
description: Come and watch Van Jones get messy dissecting social and political issues of the day. Van Jones was a stand out during the 2016 election cycle by speaking authentically, often disagreeing with both Democrats and Republicans alike.  Van's passionate on-air debates with his CNN colleagues and his heartfelt appeals to viewers were chronicled by the New York Times, Variety, Rolling Stone, and many more. Van is currently an on-air commentator for CNN and hosts the CNN special, The Messy Truth, where he builds bridges between people divided in the current political climate. He is also is the President of Dream Corps, a thriving nonprofit that seeks to close the prison doors and open the doors of opportunity. His #LoveArmy has become a broad movement for justice in the Trump era.

title: No More Bacon Ipsum: High Content Fidelity Design
speaker: Gaby Moreno Cesar
description: More and more companies see the value of designing with real data from the early stages of the design process. Unfortunately it’s not always easy to gain access to this data from a design standpoint. Tools like InVision try and help designers bring data from APIs into their workflow but yet don't expose the full capabilities of an API.

title: AfMobile Enables Ecommerce, Broadcasting in Africa
speaker: Brett Loubser
description: Mobile is booming in Africa, as is social media. One app, WeChat, aims to bring social media and e-commerce together in one place. With some 700-million users in China, WeChat is growing its user base in Africa: bringing a range of new services to Africa - especially its Wallet that allows for e-commerce via mobile.

title: LGBT in Tech Meet Up
speaker: Kate Kimpel
description: Join us as we discuss how tech companies are fostering a culture of inclusion, and how government can further incentivize. Meet and mingle with a member of Congress and LGBT policy advocate for an insightful discussion.

title: Type Safety in Javascript, Really?
speaker: Brameshmadhav Srinivasan
description: Libraries and toolkits for making Javascript type safe are on the rise. The motive is to make Javascript strictly typed. But does this really matter? Is not dynamic typing one of the strengths of Javascript and making it strictly typed an antipattern and impediment to Javascript? What will be the future of libraries like Typescript and Facebook's Flow? How is the adoption rate of strict typing in Frameworks and toolkits like AngularJS, ReactJS, and EmberJS? These questions will be answered in this session. The idea of this session is inspired by a white paper - "Type Safety for JavaScript" by Dr.Ben Weber (Department of Computer Science, University of California).

title: Austin's Untapped Brainpower: Connecting Generations
speaker: Carol Thompson
description: Austin is becoming a place where an abundance of seniors are moving and living in the Austin Region. Connecting generations in the age of longevity represents untapped brainpower in every facet of society from technology and health care to civic leadership  and business. Mentorship goes two way. Technology has driven learning to become life long. You can’t replace experience and wisdom.  Whether a newcomer, life long, young or senior, everyone needs an exchange of relationships, ideas, and experiences.

title: 101 on Women's Health: More Than Fertility
speaker: Jeffery Alvarez
description: When we talk about women's health, we often focus solely on fertility. However, this panel will dive into topics that are normally shied away: menstrual blood, infections, sex, breastfeeding, masturbation, and more. They will discuss the up-and-coming innovations in this space.

title: Grand Canyon to Everest: Sexism at All Altitudes
speaker: Abigail Wise
description: The pay gap is a problem across the board, but it’s increasingly being exposed in the outdoor industry. On average, female agricultural workers earn 65 percent of what men in the industry earn, female photographers earn 75 percent, and women who work in fitness earn 81 percent on average. The glaring lack of female leadership among large gear companies, widespread sexual harassment of guides at national parks, and the sexualization of female athletes by the media makes sexism in the outdoor industry a problem we can no longer ignore. But is this new or are we just noticing now? Do efforts such as public surveys, task forces, and social media campaigns work?

title: Not Another Valley: Startup Hubs in Latin America
speaker: Bruno Peroni
description: It is common to hear the claim of policy makers, politicians and media to build the next Silicon Valley, but this is just impossible. The Valley was born in a unique context and it is not replicable. So how do we create the same magic of the Valley in Latin America where resources are scarce and the economy is less dynamic? And how can entrepreneurs and organizations foster entrepreneurship ecosystems in regions with scarce resources when there is no role model? We will hear the experiences of representatives from startup hubs in Latin America (Brazil, Colombia and Mexico) in order to understand how organizations are working to hack the status-quo culture to build innovative companies.

title: Your New Best Friend: People-Powered Innovation
speaker: David Price
description: What do skateboards, mountain bikes, continuous glucose monitors and potato chips have in common? They were all innovations by you - and the rest of us. Customers have become prosumers, creating as much as they consume. The potential for innovation, driven by people like us, is enormous, and as yet largely untapped. And it has implications for everyone involved in people operations and research and development. The technological means of production are going open, so organisations are faced with an imperative: find a way to maximise the innovation of your users, or have them eliminate you.

title: The Tacos of Texas
speaker: Jarod Neece
description: Rooted in tradición mexicana and infused with Texas food culture, tacos are some of Texans’ all-time favorite foods. In The Tacos of Texas, the taco journalists Mando Rayo and Jarod Neece take us on a muy sabroso taco tour around the state as they discover the traditions, recipes, stories, and personalities behind puffy tacos in San Antonio, trompo tacos in Dallas, breakfast tacos in Austin, carnitas tacos in El Paso, fish tacos in Corpus Christi, barbacoa in the Rio Grande Valley, y más. The Tacos of Texas is the indispensable guidebook, cookbook, and testimonio.

title: Featured Speaker: Alexis Ohanian
speaker: Alexis Ohanian
description: Alexis is the cofounder of Reddit, bestselling author of Without Their Permission, and an activist for the open internet. He currently spends his free time investing in and advising startups.

title: Using Big Data to Better the Environment Meet Up
speaker: Christopher Ripley
description:
Many sectors of society are entirely un-sexy. But frequently within the “un-sexy” there are opportunities to generate massive social good. For instance, Smarter Sorting utilized a big data approach to solve one of the world’s oldest problems: trash. 
Come meet the Smarter Sorting team and join the discussion as we share tips and experiences on how to use data and creative solutions to better the environment.

title: Mentor Session: Louise Doherty
speaker: Louise Doherty
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Mentor Session: Anita Dolce Vita
speaker: Anita Dolce Vita
description: This session requires RSVP, and access will only be available to badge types listed under “Primary Access.” More information coming soon.

title: Mind the Machines: Neurotech and AI for Brain Health
speaker: Arshya Vahabzadeh
description: Neuroscience innovation is colliding with digital technology in unprecedented ways. Advances in machine learning, AI, and VRl/AR are revolutionizing brain health. The ramifications are profound as treatment of brain and mental health disorders will be transformed. The new tools are powerful and the concomitant ethical issues loom large. This panel includes leading experts from Neurosurgery, Psychiatry, and AR/VR that are driving the Neuro-Revolution. They will debate the future of “closed loop” brain-computer interfaces, how emerging neuro-technologies will be delivered inside and outside the traditional medical setting, and the projected impact of the neuro-revolution on our world at large.

title: (10)99 Problems and W-2s Ain't One
speaker: Isaac Madan
description: It’s no surprise – tech entrepreneurs are answering the call of Americans hungry for upward mobility (your rideshare driver has two jobs, student loans, and wants to be a homeowner one day). New income opportunities for people tired of not getting ahead are flooding the on-demand economy, while employers are hiring contractors to avoid benefits and the ACA. Welcome to the new normal, where the unbundling of the American workforce is rapidly growing the number of 1099 workers, part-timers, and full-timers with a side gig to 66 million by 2020. Hear about the future of work from tech giants and investors who support this crusade for life, liberty and the pursuit of independence.

title: Fighting Blindness with Tech Innovation and Access
speaker: Corrie  Pelc
description: Millions of people go blind every year because they can't get access to the care they need. There are 285 million blind or visually impaired people in the world; four in five of them suffer from conditions that are preventable or curable.  Our session curates key players in the eye health, MedTech and social impact spaces to discuss how we can fight avoidable blindness with the intersection of tech innovation and healthcare.  We will feature a video & discussion of the world’s only Flying Eye Hospital to show how creativity and passion can combine with science and technology to invent new ways to fight blindness. Audience members will leave feeling inspired by the ideas introduced.

title: Feelings: How Can We Suppress Them? Meet Up
speaker: Mike Boyce
description: As creators and marketers we sometimes fall into the "Me" trap. Often our own individual feelings and beliefs take center stage and cloud our ability to clearly understand and solve the problems in front of us because simply put, we're to far up our own asses.

title: Fierce Conversations: Succeeding at Work & in Life
speaker: Susan Scott
description:
While no single conversation is guaranteed to change the trajectory of a career, a company, a relationship, or a life, any single conversation can. Susan Scott, best-selling author and leadership development architect, has seen this to be true in her decades of working with companies ranging from start-ups to Fortune 100. Susan will share how you can transform your results by focusing on how you engage in your conversations. 
Topics discussed will include: 
Overcoming barriers to meaningful communication.
Expanding and enriching relationships with colleagues, friends, and family
Increasing clarity and improving understanding.
How to handle strong emotions--on both sides of the table
Connecting with colleagues, customers and family at a deep level.
